In the United States, the rising incidence and mortality rates from this primary hepatobiliary cancer, particularly over the past decade or so, have coincided with a rapidly growing interest among clinicians, investigators, and patient advocates seeking greater mechanistic insights and more personalized targeted molecular and immunotherapeutic approaches for managing and/or preventing this challenging and biologically complex hepatobiliary cancer. This first of its kind FASEB Catalyst Conference highlighted timely research findings focused on key molecular drivers, the tumor reactive stroma, and immune milieu in relation to CCA development, malignant progression, morpho-molecular heterogeneity, and therapeutic resistance, together with emerging strategies for advancing novel molecular and immunotherapies for CCA. The Keynote Address was given by Dr. Gregory J. Gores (Mayo Clinic College of Medicine and Science, Rochester, MN, USA), who provided a comprehensive review of the classification, epidemiology, morpho-molecular subtypes, experimental models, and emerging therapeutic strategies for CCA. He reviewed the worldwide incidence of this cancer, risk factors, and the anatomic subtypes. In addition, the role of driver mutations in the intrahepatic subtype of CCA was extensively discussed, with an emphasis on FGFR-2 fusions, and isocitrate dehydrogenase (IDH) 1 and 2 gain of function genetic aberrations. Precision medicine advances in treating these cancers was examined in detail including tailoring therapy for patients with B-Raf mutations, mismatch DNA repair, and the IDH and FGFR gene aberrations. Other oncogenic signaling pathways were also discussed. Finally, an appraisal from a therapeutic perspective of the tumor immune microenvironment was dissected in detail. The disappointing response to checkpoint inhibitors was noted, and the opportunities for therapies combining immune checkpoint inhibitors with targeting of other immune cell subtypes were noted. Two Plenary Sessions followed the Keynote Address. The topic of Plenary Session 1 was Tumor Microenvironment. That of Plenary Session 2 was Molecular Drivers and Targets. In Plenary Session 1, Dr. Mario Strazzabosco (Yale University School of Medicine, New Haven, CT, USA) presented a detailed discussion of the tumor microenvironment in CCA. He noted the strikingly heterogeneous and diversified ecosystem generated by signals originating from the cancer cells and including inflammatory cytokines and growth factors, in particular, PDGFs, TGFβ, and VEGFs. These signals are coordinated and amplified by a unique population of mesenchymal stromal cells called cancer-associated fibroblasts (CAFs), which are activated myofibroblasts largely originating from hepatic stellate cells and/or portal fibroblasts. Recent data obtained through single-cell transcriptomics were discussed, identifying at least five different clusters of CAFs in CCA, each of them with a specific function. He further noted that among CCA types, there is substantial variation in the cellular and matrisome composition of the tumor microenvironment, and this may have important impacts on CCA invasiveness, with CCA characterized by more intense CAF infiltration showing a worse prognosis. This was further illustrated by data demonstrating VEGF-C secreted by CAFs to promote lymphangiogenesis and facilitate the migration of CCA cells into the lymphatic vessels. The role of innate and adaptive immunity in CCA was also discussed, which highlighted further complexity and heterogeneity in the CCA microenvironment with respect to immune regulation and predictive relationships with immunotherapeutic responses and prognosis. Dr. Sumera I. Ilyas (Mayo Clinic College of Medicine and Science) then discussed the role of immunosuppressive myeloid cells in CCA. She pointed out that CCAs are desmoplastic tumors with an innate tumor immune microenvironment that is enriched in immunosuppressive myeloid cells, such as tumor-associated macrophages (TAMs) and myeloid-derived suppressor cells (MDSCs). Dr. Ilyas presented preclinical data demonstrating that there is a significant increase in programmed death ligand-1 (PD-L1)-positive TAMs in CCA. These PD-L1-positive TAMs promote exhaustion of cytotoxic T lymphocytes and foster tumor progression in CCA. However, inhibition of TAMs promotes a compensatory emergence of granulocytic-MDSCs (G-MDSCs). Dual inhibition of G-MDSCs and TAMs potentiates immune checkpoint blockade in CCA with consequent reduction in CCA tumor burden and improvement in survival in a murine model. Dr. Ilyas discussed that these findings support the role of combination immunotherapeutic strategies coupling immune checkpoint blockade with immunotherapies targeting tumor-promoting myeloid cells in CCA. Dr. Daniela Sia (Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai, New York, NY, USA) opened Plenary Session 2 with a presentation discussing the current status of molecular classifications of intrahepatic and extrahepatic CCA. She stressed the different molecular and immune profiles of these two CCA subtypes and the importance of considering them as separate entities. She also presented her recent progress in generating a novel genomics-based classification of intrahepatic CCA, so called stroma-tumor-immune-based (STIM) classification, able to integrate aberrations of the tumor with immune and stromal features. The proposed classification pinpoints potential tumor-intrinsic and tumor-extrinsic mechanisms of immunosuppression and evasion, and ultimately provide insights into the rational design of therapeutic strategies targeting both the cancer cells and the surrounding microenvironment. Dr. Nabeel Bardeesy (Massachusetts General Hospital, Harvard Medical School, Boston, MA, USA) then discussed the subset of intrahepatic CCAs harboring mutations in the metabolic gene, IDH1. Gain of function IDH1 mutations are among the most common genetic alterations in intrahepatic CCA, and act by generating high levels of the metabolite (R)-2-hydroxyglutarate [(R)-2HG]. (R)-2HG inhibits the function of numerous enzymes that are dependent on α-ketoglutarate, including histone and DNA demethylating enzymes, although the critical targets of (R)-2HG that drive intrahepatic CCA initiation and the functions of mIDH1 in fully formed tumors remain undefined. Likewise, small molecule selective mIDH1 inhibitors provide clinical benefit for patients with mIDH1 intrahepatic CCA, although the mechanisms are not clear. Dr. Bardeesy presented findings regarding the biological and molecular basis for response to mIDH1 inhibition in a novel genetically engineered mouse model (GEMM). He showed that mIDH1 promotes immuno-evasion in intrahepatic CCA and that restoration of antitumor immunity is central to the therapeutic efficacy of mIDH1 inhibition in the GEMM. Moreover, he presented data revealing that mIDH1 inhibition confers sensitivity to immune checkpoint inhibition. The Plenary Sessions were followed by an important clinically oriented Virtual Roundtable Discussion focused on the challenges and future of precision medicine in CCA. This open panel discussion, which was moderated by Dr. Sirica, included presentations by Dr. Tim F. Greten (National Cancer Institute, U.S. National Institutes of Health, Bethesda, MD, USA), Dr. Lewis R. Roberts (Mayo Clinic College of Medicine and Science), Dr. Nilo Azad (Johns Hopkins School of Medicine, Baltimore, MD, USA), and Stacie C. Lindsey (The Cholangiocarcinoma Foundation, Herriman, UT, USA). Dr. Greten discussed current immune-based approaches in biliary tract cancer. A number of studies including trials conducted at the National Cancer Institute suggest that single agent checkpoint inhibitor therapy is not very successful in biliary tract cancer. Dr. Greten presented preclinical data of a very potent immune-based approach testing the combination of anti-CD40/anti-PD1 in combination with chemotherapy leading to significant survival in mice with large established tumors. He also pointed out that myeloid cells are frequently found in the tumor microenvironment of biliary tract cancers and represent an important target to enhance antitumor immunity. It was then noted by Dr. Roberts that there is a substantial gap in knowledge about the potential for inherited genetic risk for CCA in populations of all ethnicities. He and his collaborators have initiated a global genome-wide association study to identify gene variants associated with the development of CCA. Their initial discovery phase cohort is comprised primarily of patients of European ancestry, with a small proportion of persons of Asian ancestry. With the development of novel statistical analysis techniques that allow adjustment for differences in racial and ethnic background of participants, they now seek to enhance the scope of the study by adding a substantial number of persons of Hispanic, Asian, and African descent with CCA, and thus gain additional knowledge of risk variants important in underrepresented populations. A majority of patients being treated for CCA are diagnosed with unresectable tumor, thus limiting their treatment options. Dr. Nilo Azad indicated that for these patients, there are presently only two lines of systemic chemotherapy, both of which are not curative. This speaks to a significant unmet need for new therapies. In this context, she stated that there are multiple strategies we could employ to add new agents to the options available for CCA patients, including using novel agent drugs that are emerging for known targets that previously have not been druggable and finding new uses of already approved drugs as single agents or more likely in combination approaches. Adding to what was presented in the Keynote Address and in Plenary Session 2, she further emphasized the use of FGFR inhibitors for FGFR-rearranged tumors, IDH1 inhibitors for IDH1 mutated tumors, and combination RAF/MEK inhibitors in BRAF v600-mutated tumors as being examples of employing already known agents for biomarker-targeted cohorts of CCA. Moreover, she noted that there are still multiple biomarker subsets, including patients with DNA damage repair defects such as BRCA1/2 mutations, ARID1A mutations, and KRAS mutations, among many others, where novel approaches are being tested and are needed. Stacie Lindsey, Founder and CEO of the Cholangiocarcinoma Foundation, followed with a discussion of the importance of biomarker testing for patients with CCA. She went on to explain that there are several reasons patients do not get biomarker testing, based on the foundation’s survey data. The most critical reason is that their provider does not tell them about it. This is a far more common occurrence in community practice rather than academic institutions. However, the survey found both circumstances. Advocacy plays a key role in educating patients on the importance of biomarker testing, which opens the door to many clinical trials, and targeted treatment options. Here she advocated that every patient with CCA should have biomarker testing. It was further stated by her that while patients may not choose to participate in a clinical trial or take advantage of targetable treatment options, they still should know the options available to them and have the opportunity to make this decision. Additional points of discussion raised at this conference called attention to the challenges of (1) intra- and intertumoral heterogeneity as a major obstacle to the development of molecular targeted-based and immune-based therapies for CCA; (2) the need to develop an integrated systems biology approach to classifying distinct CCA subtypes, predictive of prognosis and therapeutic outcomes; (3) continued research aimed at improving preclinical CCA testing models that can more accurately translate to novel human CCA therapies; and (4) expanding clinical therapeutic trials to include early stage CCA. Results from the evaluation survey were very positive concerning the relevance and quality of research discussed, with 78.57% of the respondents being in strong agreement and 21.43% and 14.29%, respectively, being in agreement, with no negative comments. Moreover, 85.71% of those responding to the survey stated that they would be interested in attending the meeting again in the future, either virtually or in person, with an additional 7.14% responding yes to in person only, and another 7.14% to virtually only. Longitudinal research is one effective way to gauge changes in a student cohort over time, however attrition in these studies is typically high, which can result in study bias. This study explored learning environment factors, approaches to studying, and academic performance as predictors of occupational therapy students' consistent participation in data collection conducted over three years of their professional program.A longitudinal study of Norwegian occupational therapy students (analyzed n = 240) was conducted. Logistic regression analysis was used to explore occupational therapy students' perceptions of the learning environment, their approaches to studying, and exam grades as they related to the likelihood of consistent participation at three annual surveys.Annual response rates varied between 55.1%, and 65.6%, and consistent participation was observed among 49.2%. The fully adjusted regression models showed that higher strategic approach scores increased the odds of consistent participation (adjusted OR: 1.04, p < 0.01), whereas higher surface approach scores decreased the odds of consistent participation (adjusted OR: 0.95, p < 0.05). Neither sociodemographic factors, learning environment factors nor academic performance predicted participation over time.Researchers can anticipate relatively high levels of attrition in longitudinal studies of occupational therapy students, but attrition seems to be largely proportional between groups. However, completers in longitudinal studies may be somewhat more well-organized and academically oriented than drop-outs.
